And by the way I find this "use some tools and be a l337 hacker that would deceive the NSA" super ludicrous. It doesn't really help if you use Tor and a simple malfunction in let's say a memory bus in your system can give you away. In my experience with computing I have witnessed that its these little faggot details that make the difference. So in the question in part: How does someone have to do to get the expertise I would recommend going exactly through 3 phases of learning. A) Programming : Learn a full compiled language like C or Java. In most undergraduate programmes they tend to teach Java as a first language as it is high level, object-oriented and friendly to begginners as they don't have to mess with things like memory management etc. But I find that teaching C as a first language can reap its benefits. It's mostly function oriented, really a pain in the ass in managing memory and such, but due to its nature it trains the person to think in binary vision and in detail and as such it provides the foundations for a smooth transition to more delicate fields of computer programming i.e Assembly (a must have if your serious about what you do) . Java doesn't do that and that's a main reason why most students on their second year that employed a transition to C++ and Assembly, took a serious blow to the gut. So my take would be to take C as a first language. Study it thorougly for six months until you reach the point of making nice applications with it. Then move to C++ and Assembly for more delicate stuff. You will see that after 1 or 2 years (taking in mind that you do daily and thorough practice) you will witness that you will learn new languages in a second. Computer theory: Networking, operating systems and computer architecture and how these intertwine. If you like to take the edge of it some linear algebra, algorithm computation theory would'nt hurt either. Thank goodness they're platforms like Coursera these days that handle subjects like that so you won't to have to enlist in a computer department just to learn this stuff. C) Real life application: Get Virtualbox, make some virtual machines and screw the hell out of them.... At start you should put more emphasis on stage A, with little attention to B and none to C(you won't need so much in this point). As time progresses shift your emphasis in B and when you get a hold of that try C. Later the A,B,C stages will be balanced. A last point need to be made. Anonymity, security and all that when we talk about computing are a discipline on their own. So using just Tor won't do you any good if you don't know how it works and what can screw it over. And if it will not screw your over, then luck is to be held accountable and not skill. Now luck is a double edged sword because it helps, but it can also fuck you up badly. With proper technique you can minimize the extend that you rely on luck, and be more on the safe side.
